title: Labour will not vote for snap election next week, says Thornberry
text:
Emily Thornberry has confirmed Labour will not vote for a snap election on Monday when the prime minister is expected to try again for an October poll.

Speaking to BBC Radio 4’s Today programme, the shadow foreign secretary suggested the party had settled on a view that it needed to ensure the prospect of a no-deal Brexit was ruled out before it could back an early election.

And she linked the issue of the timing of the election with questions over the honesty of the prime minister.

She said: “If we vote to have a general election, then no matter what it is that Boris Johnson promises, it up to him to advise the Queen when the general election should be. And given that he has shown himself to be a manifest liar and somebody who has said he would ‘die in a ditch’ rather than stop no deal … our first priority has to be that we must stop no deal and we must make sure that that is going to happen.”

The government has suggested it will hold a vote on another motion under the Fixed-term Parliaments Act on Monday, a procedure that requires two-thirds of MPs to back it if it is to pass.

Thornberry’s comments appear to confirm that Labour will reject for a second time any attempt to call an election on 15 October, despite Conservative taunts that it is fearful of the outcome.

She said Johnson was “as slippery as can be” and could not be trusted over the timing of polling day.

She suggested Labour would back an election in November after an extension to Brexit had been agreed. She said: “We are not talking about very long, are we, but we need to get this immediate crisis dealt with first.”

She also appeared to rule out Labour calling for a no-confidence motion in the government next week. “Looking at the rules it would be difficult for us to have a successful motion of no confidence,” she said.

Thornberry insisted Labour was “united” with opposition parties on the need to rule out a no-deal Brexit before backing an election. She said: “The possibility of having a general election obviously is extremely attractive, but we have an immediate crisis in front of us and that has to be sorted before we do anything else.

“Unfortunately, given the behaviour of the prime minister and his advisers, we need to be absolutely sure that we are not going to end up in a situation where the general election is used as a distraction while they, by some cunning wheeze, bounce us out of the European Union without a deal.”

Her comments echo remarks she made on BBC’s Question Time on Thursday night, when she said: “We want a general election. Of course we do, [but] at the moment the emergency is we have a dishonest prime minister who will use every means possible to get us out of the European Union without a deal.”

Thornberry also confirmed Labour was set to a back a second referendum in its manifesto. She said: “If we won the general election we would need to put a viable way of leaving the EU that had been negotiated with jobs and the economy at the forefront of our minds versus remain. Whatever deal was finally agreed by whatever government, we would demand a referendum.”

She added: “On the basis of what Jeremy [Corbyn] has said we would need to put a viable leave option against remain. There would be a referendum and it would be for the good sense of the British people to decide which way we went forward. This is proper democracy. We have been struggling with this for three years but in the end we are deferential to the will of the people and it has been a long time since the last referendum.”
description: Shadow foreign secretary says no-deal Brexit must be ruled out before party can back poll
